translation: The proverbs of Solomon son of David, king of Israel.
To know wisdom and instruction; to understand words of insight.
To receive instruction in wise conduct, in righteousness and justice and uprightness.
To give prudence to the simple, to the young man knowledge and discretion.
A wise man will hear and increase learning, and a man of understanding will acquire wise counsels.
To understand a proverb and a figure, the words of the wise and their riddles.
The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge; fools despise wisdom and instruction.
Hear, my son, the discipline of your father, and do not forsake the teaching of your mother.
For they shall be a garland of grace to your head and chains for your neck.
My son, if sinners entice you, do not consent.
If they say, “Come with us, let us lie in wait for blood; let us lurk secretly for the innocent without cause.”
Let us swallow them alive like Sheol, and whole, like those who go down to the pit.
All precious wealth we shall find; we shall fill our houses with spoil.
Cast your lot among us; we shall all have one purse.
My son, do not walk in the way with them; hold back your foot from their path.
For their feet run to evil, and they make haste to shed blood.
For in vain is the net spread in the sight of every bird of the wing.
But they lie in wait for their own blood; they lurk secretly for their own lives.
So are the paths of everyone who gains unjust gain; it takes away the life of its possessors.
Wisdom cries aloud in the street; in the open squares she lifts up her voice.
At the head of the noisy streets she cries out; at the entrances of the gates in the city she speaks her words.
How long, O simple ones, will you love simplicity, and scoffers delight themselves in scoffing, and fools hate knowledge?
Turn back at my reproof; behold, I will pour out my spirit to you, I will make my words known to you.
Because I called and you refused, I stretched out my hand and no one paid heed.
but you have disregarded all my counsel, and would have none of my reproof.
I also, in your calamity, will laugh; I will mock when your dread comes.
When terror comes upon you like a storm, and your calamity sweeps in like a whirlwind; when distress and anguish come upon you.
Then shall they call upon me, but I will not answer; they shall seek me early, but they shall not find me.
Because they hated knowledge and did not choose the fear of the LORD.
They would not consent to my counsel; they despised all my reproof.
So they shall eat of the fruit of their own way, and be filled with their own counsels.
For the turning away of the simple shall slay them, and the complacency of fools shall destroy them.
But whoever listens to me shall dwell in safety, and be at ease from fear of evil.
My son, if you receive my words and treasure up my commandments within you,
To make your ear attentive to wisdom, you incline your heart to understanding.
Yes, if you call out for understanding, and lift up your voice for discernment.
If you seek her as silver, and search for her as for hidden treasures.
Then you will understand the fear of the LORD, and you will find the knowledge of God.
For the LORD gives wisdom; from His mouth come knowledge and understanding.
He stores up sound wisdom for the upright; he is a shield to those who walk in integrity.
to guard the paths of justice and preserve the way of His faithful ones
Then you will understand righteousness and justice and uprightness, every good path.
For wisdom will enter your heart, and knowledge will be pleasant to your soul.
Discretion will watch over you; understanding will guard you.
To deliver you from the way of evil, from the man who speaks perverse things.
Who forsake the paths of uprightness, to walk in ways of darkness.
Who rejoice to do evil, and exult in the perversities of evil.
whose paths are crooked, and who are devious in their ways.
To deliver you from the strange woman, from the foreign woman who smooths her words.
Who forsakes the companion of her youth and forgets the covenant of her God.
For her house sinks down to death, and her paths to the shades of the dead.
None that go to her return, nor do they attain the paths of life.
So that you may walk in the way of the good, and keep to the paths of the righteous.
For the upright shall dwell in the land, and the blameless shall remain in it.
But the wicked shall be cut off from the land, and the treacherous shall be torn away from it.
My son, do not forget my teaching, but let your heart keep my commandments.
For length of days and years of life and peace shall they add to you.
Let mercy and truth not forsake you; bind them upon your neck, write them on the tablet of your heart.
So you will find favor and good understanding in the sight of God and man.
Trust in the LORD with all your heart, and do not lean on your own understanding.
In all your ways acknowledge Him, and He will make straight your paths.
Do not be wise in your own eyes; fear the LORD, and turn away from evil.
It shall be healing to your flesh and refreshment to your bones.
Honor the LORD with your wealth, and with the first of all your increase.
Then your barns will be filled with plenty, and your vats will burst forth with new wine.
My son, do not despise the discipline of the LORD, and do not loathe His reproof.
For whom the LORD loves He reproves, even as a father the son in whom he delights.
Blessed is the man who finds wisdom, and the man who obtains understanding.
For her merchandise is better than the merchandise of silver, and her gain than fine gold.
She is more precious than rubies, and all your delights cannot be compared with her.
Length of days is in her right hand; and in her left hand riches and honor.
Her ways are ways of pleasantness, and all her paths are peace.
She is a tree of life to those who lay hold of her, and blessed are those who hold her fast.
The LORD by wisdom founded the earth; by understanding he established the heavens.
By his knowledge the depths were broken open, and the skies distill the dew.
My son, let them not depart from your eyes; keep sound wisdom and discretion.
And they shall be life to your soul, and grace to your neck.
Then you shall walk in safety on your way, and your foot shall not stumble.
When you lie down, you shall not be afraid; yes, you shall lie down, and your sleep shall be sweet.
Do not be afraid of sudden terror, nor of the ruin of the wicked when it comes.
For the LORD will be your confidence, and will keep your foot from being caught.
Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due, when it is in the power of your hand to do it.
Do not say to your neighbor, “Go, and come again, and tomorrow I will give,” when you have it with you.
Do not plot evil against your neighbor, while he dwells securely with you.
Do not contend with a man without cause, if he has done you no evil.
Do not envy a man of violence, and do not choose any of his ways.
For the perverse man is an abomination to the LORD, but His secret counsel is with the upright.
The curse of the LORD is in the house of the wicked, but the dwelling of the righteous He blesses.
Surely he scorns the scorners, but to the humble he gives grace.
Honor the wise shall inherit, but fools lift up disgrace.
Hear, O sons, the discipline of a father, and give heed, that you may know understanding.
For I give to you good instruction; do not forsake my teaching.
For I was a son to my father, tender and an only one in the sight of my mother.
And he instructed me and said to me, Let your heart hold fast my words; keep my commandments, and live.
Get wisdom; get understanding; do not forget, and do not turn away from the words of my mouth.
Do not forsake her, and she will keep you; love her, and she will guard you.
The beginning of wisdom is this: Get wisdom; and with all your acquiring, get understanding.
Exalt her, and she will lift you up; she will honor you when you embrace her.
She shall give to your head a garland of grace; a crown of glory shall she bestow upon you.
Hear, my son, and receive my sayings, and the years of your life shall be many.
In the way of wisdom I have instructed you; I have led you in paths of uprightness.
When you walk, your steps shall not be straitened, and if you run, you shall not stumble.
Take firm hold of instruction, do not let go; guard her, for she is your life.
Into the path of the wicked do not enter, and do not walk straight in the way of evil men.
Avoid it, do not pass by it; turn from it and pass on.
For they do not sleep unless they have done evil, and their sleep is taken away unless they cause someone to stumble.
For they eat the bread of wickedness, and drink the wine of violence.
But the path of the righteous is like the shining light, that shines ever brighter until the perfect day.
The way of the wicked is like deep darkness; they do not know over what they stumble.
My son, attend to my words; incline your ear to my sayings.
Let them not depart from your eyes; keep them in the midst of your heart.
For they are life to those who find them, and healing to all their flesh.
Above all that you guard, keep your heart, for from it flow the springs of life.
Put away from you a crooked mouth, and perverse lips put far from you.
Let your eyes look straight ahead, and let your eyelids gaze right before you.
Make level the path of your feet, and let all your ways be established.
Do not turn to the right or to the left; remove your foot from evil.
My son, attend to my wisdom; incline your ear to my understanding.
That you may keep discretion, and that knowledge may guard your lips.
For the lips of a strange woman drip honeycomb, and her palate is smoother than oil.
But her end is bitter as wormwood, sharp as a two-edged sword.
Her feet go down to death; her steps take hold on Sheol.
The path of life she does not ponder; her ways wander, and she does not know it.
And now, O sons, listen to me, and do not turn aside from the words of my mouth.
Keep your way far from her, and do not come near the door of her house.
Lest you give your honor to others, and your years to the cruel.
Lest strangers be filled with your strength, and your labors be in the house of a foreigner.
And you will groan at your latter end, when your flesh and your body are consumed.
And you will say, “How I hated instruction, and my heart despised reproof.”
And I did not listen to the voice of my instructors, nor incline my ear to my teachers.
I was almost in all evil in the midst of the congregation and assembly.
Drink waters from your own cistern, and flowing streams from the midst of your own well.
Let your springs be dispersed abroad, streams of water in the streets.
Let them be yours alone, and not for strangers with you.
Let your fountain be blessed, and rejoice in the wife of your youth.
A loving doe, a graceful mountain goat—let her breasts satisfy you at all times; in her love may you always be enraptured.
And why, my son, will you go astray with a strange woman, and embrace the bosom of a foreigner?
For the ways of a man are before the eyes of the LORD, and He weighs all his paths.
His own iniquities shall capture the wicked, and by the cords of his sin he shall be held fast.
He shall die for lack of discipline, and in the greatness of his folly he shall go astray.
My son, if you have become surety for your neighbor, if you have struck your hands in pledge with a stranger,
You are snared by the words of your mouth, you are taken by the words of your mouth.
Do this now, my son, and deliver yourself, for you have come into the hand of your neighbor; go, humble yourself, and plead with your neighbor.
Do not give sleep to your eyes, nor slumber to your eyelids.
Deliver yourself like a gazelle from the hand of the hunter, and like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
Go to the ant, O sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise.
Which has no chief, overseer, or ruler.
She prepares her bread in the summer, she gathers her food in the harvest.
How long, O sluggard, will you lie down? When will you arise from your sleep?
A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to lie down.
And your poverty shall come like a prowler, and your want like an armed man.
A worthless man, a man of iniquity, walks with perversity of mouth.
Winking with his eyes, shuffling with his feet, pointing with his fingers.
Perversities are in his heart; he devises evil continually; he sends forth strife.
Therefore his calamity shall come suddenly; in an instant he shall be broken, and there shall be no healing.
These six things the LORD hates, indeed seven are an abomination to His soul.
Haughty eyes, a lying tongue, and hands that shed innocent blood.
A heart that devises wicked plans, feet that are swift to run to evil.
A false witness who breathes out lies, and one who sows strife between brothers.
Keep, my son, the commandment of your father, and do not forsake the teaching of your mother.
Bind them upon your heart continually; fasten them about your neck.
When you walk, it shall lead you; when you lie down, it shall watch over you; and when you awake, it shall speak with you.
For the commandment is a lamp, and the teaching is light, and reproofs of discipline are the way of life.
To keep you from the evil woman, from the smooth tongue of the foreign woman.
Do not lust after her beauty in your heart, nor let her capture you with her eyelids.
For on account of a harlot a man is brought to a loaf of bread, but another man’s wife hunts down a precious life.
Can a man take fire into his bosom, and his garments not be burned?
Can a man walk upon hot coals, and his feet not be burned?
So is he who goes in to his neighbor’s wife; whoever touches her shall not be unpunished.
Men do not despise a thief if he steals to satisfy his soul when he is hungry.
But if he is found, he shall repay sevenfold; he shall give all the wealth of his house.
He who commits adultery with a woman is lacking heart; he who does it destroys his own soul.
Wound and dishonor he will find, and his reproach shall not be wiped away.
For jealousy is the fury of a man, and he will not spare in the day of vengeance.
He will accept no ransom, nor will he consent though you multiply gifts.
My son, keep my words, and treasure up my commandments with you.
Keep my commandments and live, and my teaching as the apple of your eye.
Bind them upon your fingers; write them upon the tablet of your heart.
Say to wisdom, “You are my sister,” and call understanding your close kinswoman.
To keep you from the strange woman, from the foreign woman who smooths her words.
For at the window of my house I looked out through my lattice.
And I beheld among the simple ones, I discerned among the youths, a young man void of understanding.
Passing through the street near her corner, and he takes the way to her house.
In the twilight, in the evening of the day, in the pupil of the night and in the darkness.
And behold, a woman comes to meet him, dressed as a harlot and guarded of heart.
She is boisterous and rebellious; in her house her feet do not abide.
Now in the street, now in the squares, and at every corner she lies in wait.
She caught him and kissed him; she hardened her face and said to him,
Sacrifices of peace offerings are upon me; this day I have paid my vows.
Therefore I came out to meet you, to seek your face early, and I have found you.
With coverlets I have spread my couch, with embroidered linens from Egypt.
I have perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.
Come, let us drink our fill of love until the morning; let us delight ourselves with loves.
For the man is not in his house; he has gone on a journey far away.
He has taken the bag of money in his hand; he will come home at the appointed day.
She caused him to yield by the greatness of her persuasions; with the smoothness of her lips she drove him away.
He goes after her suddenly, like an ox to the slaughter he comes, and like a fetter to the correction of a fool.
Till an arrow pierces through his liver; as a bird hastens to the snare, and he does not know that it is for his life.
And now, children, listen to me, and give heed to the words of my mouth.
Let not your heart turn aside to her ways; do not stray into her paths.
For many are the slain whom she has cast down, and mighty are all her slain.
Her house is the ways to Sheol, going down to the chambers of death.
Does not wisdom call, and understanding lift up her voice?
On the heights beside the way, at the crossroads of the paths she takes her stand.
Beside the gates, at the entrance of the city, at the coming in of the doors, she cries aloud.
To you, O men, I call, and my voice is to the children of man.
Understand, O simple ones, prudence; and you fools, understand heart.
Hear, for noble things I will speak, and the opening of my lips shall be upright things.
For my mouth shall utter truth, and wickedness is an abomination to my lips.
In righteousness are all the sayings of my mouth; there is in them nothing twisted or perverse.
They are all plain to him who understands, and upright to those who find knowledge.
Receive instruction, and not silver, and knowledge rather than choice gold.
For wisdom is better than rubies, and all that you may desire cannot be compared with her.
I, wisdom, dwell with prudence, and I find knowledge of wise counsels.
The fear of the LORD is to hate evil; pride and arrogance and the evil way and the perverse mouth I do hate.
Counsel is mine, and sound wisdom; I am understanding, I have strength.
By me kings reign, and rulers decree justice.
By me princes rule, and nobles, all the judges of righteousness.
I love those who love Me, and those who seek Me early shall find Me.
Riches and honor are with me, enduring wealth and righteousness.
My fruit is better than gold, even fine gold, and my yield than choice silver.
In the path of righteousness I walk, in the midst of the tracks of justice.
To cause those who love me to inherit substance, and I will fill their treasuries.
The LORD possessed me at the beginning of His way, before His works of old.
From everlasting I was set in place, from the beginning, from the earliest times of the earth.
When there were no depths, I was brought forth, when there were no fountains abounding with water.
Before the mountains were settled, before the hills I was brought forth.
Before he made the earth and the open fields, and the first clods of the world.
When He established the heavens, there was I; when He inscribed a circle upon the face of the deep.
When He made firm the skies above, when He strengthened the fountains of the deep.
When He assigned to the sea its decree, that the waters should not pass His command, when He marked out the foundations of the earth.
Then I was beside Him, a master workman, and I was His delight day by day, rejoicing before Him at all times.
Playing in the world, his earth, and my delight was with the sons of man.
And now, children, listen to me, and blessed are those who keep my ways.
Hear instruction and be wise, and do not neglect it.
Blessed is the man who listens to me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my doors.
For whoever finds me finds life, and obtains favor from the LORD.
But he who sins against me wrongs his own soul; all who hate me love death.
Wisdom has built her house; she has hewn out her seven pillars.
She has slaughtered her slaughter, she has mixed her wine; she has also set in order her table.
She has sent forth her maidens; she calls upon the highest places of the city.
Whoever is simple, let him turn in here; to him who lacks understanding she says,
Come, eat of my bread, and drink of the wine I have mixed.
Forsake the simple, and live; and walk in the way of understanding.
He who corrects a scoffer brings shame upon himself, and he who rebukes a wicked man brings upon himself a blemish.
Do not reprove a scoffer, lest he hate you; reprove a wise man, and he will love you.
Give to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser; teach a righteous man, and he will increase in learning.
The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom, and the knowledge of the Holy One is understanding.
For by me your days shall be multiplied, and years of life shall be added to you.
If you are wise, you are wise for yourself; and if you scoff, you alone will bear it.
The woman of folly is boisterous, simple-minded, and knows nothing at all.
She sits at the doorway of her house, upon a seat on the heights of the city.
To call to those who pass by on the way, who go straight on their paths.
Whoever is simple, let him turn in here; and to him who lacks heart she says,
Stolen waters are sweet, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant.
But he does not know that the dead are there, that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.
The proverbs of Solomon: A wise son makes a father glad, but a foolish son is the grief of his mother.
Treasures of wickedness do not profit, but righteousness delivers from death.
The LORD will not let the soul of the righteous go hungry, but He thrusts away the craving of the wicked.
A slack hand makes one poor, but the hand of the diligent makes rich.
He who gathers in summer is a wise son, but he who sleeps in harvest is a son who brings shame.
Blessings are upon the head of the righteous, but violence covers the mouth of the wicked.
The memory of the righteous is for a blessing, but the name of the wicked shall rot.
The wise in heart will receive commandments, but a babbling fool will be thrown into confusion.
He who walks in integrity walks securely, but he who makes his ways crooked shall be found out.
He who winks the eye causes sorrow, and a foolish of lips shall be overthrown.
The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked covers violence.
Hatred stirs up strife, but love covers all transgressions.
On the lips of him who is discerning, wisdom is found; but a rod is for the back of him who lacks heart.
The wise store up knowledge, but the mouth of a fool is near to ruin.
The rich man’s wealth is his strong city, the ruin of the poor is their poverty.
The wages of the righteous are for life, but the increase of the wicked is for sin.
The path of life is he who keeps instruction, but he who forsakes reproof leads astray.
He who covers hatred with lying lips, and he who spreads slander, is a fool.
In the multitude of words transgression does not cease, but whoever restrains his lips is prudent.
Choice silver is the tongue of the righteous, but the heart of the wicked is of little worth.
The lips of the righteous feed many, but fools die for lack of heart.
The blessing of the LORD, it makes rich, and He adds no sorrow with it.
As a sport to a fool is the doing of wickedness, so wisdom is to a man of understanding.
The dread of the wicked, it shall come upon him, but the desire of the righteous He will grant.
When the whirlwind passes, the wicked are no more, but the righteous is an everlasting foundation.
Like vinegar to the teeth and like smoke to the eyes, so is the sluggard to those who send him.
The fear of the LORD adds days, but the years of the wicked shall be cut short.
The hope of the righteous is gladness, but the expectation of the wicked shall perish.
The way of the LORD is a stronghold to the blameless, but ruin to workers of iniquity.
The righteous shall never be moved, but the wicked shall not dwell in the land.
The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but the tongue of perverseness shall be cut off.
The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable, but the mouth of the wicked is perverse.
A false balance is an abomination to the LORD, but a just weight is his delight.
When pride comes, then comes disgrace, but with the humble is wisdom.
The integrity of the upright shall guide them, but the perverseness of the treacherous shall destroy them.
Riches do not profit in the day of wrath, but righteousness delivers from death.
The righteousness of the blameless makes straight his way, but the wicked falls by his own wickedness.
The righteousness of the upright shall deliver them, but in their own wicked desire the treacherous shall be taken.
When a wicked man dies, hope perishes, and the expectation of the strong is destroyed.
The righteous is delivered out of trouble, and the wicked comes in his stead.
With the mouth of the godless a man destroys his neighbor, but through the knowledge of the righteous they are delivered.
In the good of the righteous a city rejoices, and when the wicked perish there is singing.
By the blessing of the upright a city is exalted, but by the mouth of the wicked it is overthrown.
He who despises his neighbor is lacking heart, but a man of understanding keeps silent.
A talebearer goes about revealing a secret, but one of a faithful spirit conceals a matter.
Where there is no counsel, the people fall, but in the multitude of counselors there is deliverance.
He shall be sorely broken who becomes surety for a stranger, but he who hates striking hands in pledge is secure.
A gracious woman lays hold of honor, but ruthless men lay hold of riches.
A man of kindness does good to his own soul, but he who troubles his own flesh is cruel.
The wicked earns a deceptive wage, but he who sows righteousness has a sure reward.
So righteousness leads to life, and he who pursues evil, to his own death.
Those of crooked heart are an abomination to the LORD, but those who are blameless in way are his delight.
Hand to hand, the wicked shall not go unpunished, but the seed of the righteous shall be delivered.
A gold ring in a swine’s snout, so is a beautiful woman who turns aside from discretion.
The desire of the righteous is only good, but the expectation of the wicked is wrath.
There is one who scatters, yet increases all the more, and one who withholds what is right, only to poverty.
The generous soul will be made rich, and he who waters will himself also be watered.
He who withholds grain, the people curse him; but blessing is upon the head of him who sells it.
He who earnestly seeks good seeks favor, but he who searches out evil, it shall come upon him.
He who trusts in his riches shall fall, but the righteous shall flourish like a leaf.
He who troubles his own house shall inherit wind, and the fool shall be servant to the wise in heart.
The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, and he who takes souls is wise.
Behold, the righteous is recompensed on the earth; how much more the wicked and the sinner.
Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge, but he who hates reproof is brutish.
A good man obtains favor from the LORD, but a man of wicked devices he will condemn.
A man shall not be established by wickedness, but the root of the righteous shall not be moved.
A virtuous wife is the crown of her husband, but she who brings shame is like rottenness in his bones.
The thoughts of the righteous are justice, but the schemes of the wicked are deceit.
The words of the wicked lie in wait for blood, but the mouth of the upright delivers them.
The wicked are overthrown and are no more, but the house of the righteous shall stand.
A man shall be praised according to his wisdom, but he that is perverse in heart shall be for contempt.
Better is one who is lightly esteemed and has a servant, than one who honors himself and lacks bread.
The righteous knows the life of his beast, but the mercies of the wicked are cruel.
He who works his land will be satisfied with bread, but he who pursues vain things is lacking heart.
The wicked covets the net of evil men, but the root of the righteous yields fruit.
In the transgression of lips is an evil snare, but the righteous comes forth out of trouble.
From the fruit of a man’s mouth he shall be satisfied with good, and the recompense of a man’s hands shall be rendered to him.
The way of a fool is right in his own eyes, but he who listens to counsel is wise.
A fool, in the same day, makes his vexation known, but the prudent one conceals disgrace.
He who breathes out faithfulness declares righteousness, but a false witness deceit.
There is one who speaks rashly like the thrusts of a sword, but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
The lip of truth shall be established forever, but a lying tongue is only for a moment.
Deceit is in the heart of those who devise evil, but for the counselors of peace there is joy.
No mischief shall befall the righteous, but the wicked are filled with evil.
Lying lips are an abomination to the LORD, but those who act faithfully are his delight.
A prudent man conceals knowledge, but the heart of fools proclaims folly.
The hand of the diligent will rule, but the slothful will be put to forced labor.
Anxiety in a man’s heart weighs it down, but a good word makes it glad.
The righteous is more excellent than his neighbor, but the way of the wicked leads them astray.
The slothful man does not roast his game, but the precious wealth of a man is diligence.
In the path of righteousness is life, and along its way there is no death.
A wise son heeds his father’s discipline, but a scoffer does not listen to rebuke.
From the fruit of a man’s mouth he shall eat what is good, but the soul of the treacherous is violence.
He who guards his mouth preserves his life, but he who opens wide his lips comes to ruin.
The soul of the sluggard craves and has nothing, but the soul of the diligent shall be made fat.
A righteous man hates a lying word, but the wicked brings shame and disgrace.
Righteousness guards the one of blameless way, but wickedness overthrows the sinner.
There is one who pretends to be rich, yet has nothing; and one who makes himself poor, yet has great wealth.
The ransom of a man's life is his riches, but the poor hears no rebuke.
The light of the righteous rejoices, but the lamp of the wicked shall be put out.
By pride only comes contention, but with those who take counsel is wisdom.
Wealth gotten by vanity will dwindle, but he who gathers little by little will increase it.
Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but a desire fulfilled is a tree of life.
Whoever despises the word will be destroyed, but he who fears the commandment will be repaid.
The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, to turn aside from the snares of death.
Good understanding gives favor, but the way of the treacherous is hard.
Every prudent man acts with knowledge, but a fool spreads out his folly.
A wicked messenger falls into evil, but a faithful envoy brings healing.
Poverty and disgrace befall him who rejects discipline, but he who heeds reproof shall be honored.
A desire fulfilled is sweet to the soul, but it is an abomination to fools to turn from evil.
He who walks with the wise becomes wise, but a companion of fools shall suffer harm.
Evil pursues sinners, but He repays the righteous with good.
A good man leaves an inheritance to his children’s children, but the wealth of the sinner is stored up for the righteous.
Abundant food is in the fallow ground of the poor, but there are those who are swept away for lack of justice.
He who spares his rod hates his son, but he who loves him seeks him early with discipline.
The righteous eats to the satisfying of his soul, but the belly of the wicked shall be in want.
The wise women build her house, but the foolish tears it down with her own hands.
He who walks in his uprightness fears the LORD, but he who is perverse in his ways despises Him.
In the mouth of a fool is a rod of pride, but the lips of the wise preserve them.
Where no oxen are, the manger is clean, but much increase comes by the strength of the ox.
A faithful witness will not lie, but a false witness breathes out lies.
A scoffer seeks wisdom and finds it not, but knowledge is easy to one who has understanding.
Go from the presence of a foolish man, and you will not know lips of knowledge.
The wisdom of the prudent is to understand his way, but the folly of fools is deceit.
Fools mock at guilt, but among the upright there is favor.
The heart knows its own bitterness, and a stranger does not share in its joy.
The house of the wicked shall be destroyed, but the tent of the upright shall flourish.
There is a way that seems right before a man, but its end is the ways of death.
Even in laughter the heart is pained, and the end of joy is sorrow.
The backslider in heart shall be filled with his own ways, and a good man from what is upon him.
The simple believes every word, but the prudent gives thought to his steps.
The wise fears and turns away from evil, but the fool is hot-headed and self-confident.
One who is quick to anger commits folly, but a man of wicked schemes is hated.
The simple inherit folly, but the prudent are crowned with knowledge.
The evil bow down before the good, and the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
Even his own neighbor hates the poor man, but the rich has many who love him.
He who despises his neighbor sins, but he who shows favor to the lowly, blessed is he.
Do not those who devise evil go astray? But mercy and truth are for those who devise good.
In all painful toil there is profit, but mere talk of the lips tends only to want.
The crown of the wise is their riches, but the folly of fools is folly.
A true witness delivers souls, but he who breathes out lies is deceit.
In the fear of the LORD is strong confidence, and his children shall have a refuge.
The fear of the LORD is a fountain of life, to turn one away from the snares of death.
In the multitude of people is the king’s glory, but in the lack of a people is the ruin of a ruler.
He who is slow to anger is abundant in understanding, but he who is hasty in spirit exalts folly.
A tranquil heart is life to the flesh, but envy is rottenness to the bones.
He who oppresses the poor reproaches his Maker, but he who honors Him shows favor to the needy.
In his evil the wicked is cast down, but the righteous has refuge in his death.
Wisdom rests in the heart of him who is understanding, but in the midst of fools it is made known.
Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a reproach to peoples.
The king’s favor is toward a servant who acts wisely, but his wrath shall be upon him who brings shame.
A soft answer turns away wrath, but a hurtful word stirs up anger.
The tongue of the wise makes knowledge good, but the mouth of fools pours out folly.
In every place the eyes of the LORD are watching, observing the evil and the good.
A healing tongue is a tree of life, but perverseness in it is a breaking of the spirit.
A fool despises his father’s discipline, but whoever heeds reproof grows in prudence.
In the house of the righteous is great treasure, but in the increase of the wicked it is ruined.
The lips of the wise disperse knowledge, but the heart of fools is not so.
The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the LORD, but the prayer of the upright is his delight.
The way of the wicked is an abomination to the LORD, but He loves him who pursues righteousness.
Harsh discipline is for him who forsakes the path, and he who hates reproof shall die.
Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the LORD; how much more the hearts of the children of man.
A scoffer does not love one who reproves him; he will not go to the wise.
A merry heart makes the face cheerful, but by sorrow of heart the spirit is broken.
The heart of him who has understanding seeks knowledge, but the mouth of fools feeds on folly.
All the days of the afflicted are evil, but he who is of a cheerful heart has a continual feast.
Better is a little with the fear of the LORD than great treasure and turmoil with it.
Better is a meal of herbs where love is, than a fattened ox and hatred with it.
A man of wrath stirs up strife, but one slow to anger quiets contention.
The way of the sluggard is like a hedge of thorns, but the path of the upright is a raised highway.
A wise son makes a father glad, but a foolish man despises his mother.
Folly is joy to him who lacks heart, but a man of understanding makes straight his way.
Plans are frustrated where there is no counsel, but by many counselors they are established.
Joy is to a man in the answer of his mouth, and a word in its season, how good it is.
The path of life goes upward for the wise, that he may turn away from Sheol beneath.
The house of the proud the LORD will uproot, but He will establish the boundary of the widow.
The thoughts of the wicked are an abomination to the LORD, but gracious words are pure.
He who troubles his own house is one who gains unjust profit, but he who hates bribes shall live.
The heart of the righteous ponders how to answer, but the mouth of the wicked pours forth evils.
The LORD is far from the wicked, but the prayer of the righteous He hears.
The light of the eyes gladdens the heart, and a good report makes the bones fat.
The ear that listens to the rebuke of life shall lodge among the wise.
He who rejects discipline despises his own soul, but he who listens to reproof acquires a heart.
The fear of the LORD is the discipline of wisdom, and before honor comes humility.
The plans of the heart belong to a man, but from the LORD is the answer of the tongue.
All the ways of a man are pure in his own eyes, but the LORD weighs the spirits.
Commit your works to the LORD, and your thoughts shall be established.
The LORD has made everything for its purpose, yes, even the wicked for the day of trouble.
Everyone who is proud in heart is an abomination to the LORD; hand in hand, he shall not be unpunished.
By mercy and truth iniquity is atoned for, and by the fear of the LORD one turns away from evil.
When a man’s ways please the LORD, even his enemies He makes to be at peace with him.
Better is a little with righteousness than great revenues without justice.
The heart of a man plans his way, but the LORD establishes his steps.
A divine sentence is on the lips of a king; in judgment his mouth will not betray.
Honest scales and balances are the LORD’s; all the weights of the bag are his work.
An abomination to kings is to do wickedness, for by righteousness a throne is established.
The delight of kings is righteous lips, and he who speaks what is upright is loved.
The wrath of a king is messengers of death, but a wise man will appease it.
In the light of a king’s face is life, and his favor is like a cloud of the latter rain.
To get wisdom, how much better it is than gold; and to get understanding is to be chosen rather than silver.
The highway of the upright is to turn away from evil; he who guards his soul keeps his way.
Pride goes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.
Better to be of a lowly spirit with the humble than to divide the spoil with the proud.
He who acts wisely concerning a matter will find good, and blessed is he who trusts in the LORD.
The wise in heart shall be called discerning, and sweetness of lips increases learning.
Understanding is a fountain of life to its possessor, but the discipline of fools is folly.
The heart of the wise makes his mouth discerning, and upon his lips it adds learning.
Honeycomb of honey are pleasant words, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.
There is a way that seems right before a man, but its end is the ways of death.
The appetite of the laboring man labors for him, for his mouth presses him on.
A worthless man digs up evil, and on his lips is a burning fire.
A perverse man sends forth strife, and a whisperer separates close friends.
A man of violence entices his neighbor, and leads him in a way that is not good.
He who shuts his eyes to devise perverse things, he who compresses his lips brings evil to completion.
Gray hair is a crown of splendor; it is found in the way of righteousness.
Better is one who is slow to anger than the mighty, and he who rules his spirit than one who captures a city.
The lot is cast into the lap, but its every decision is from the LORD.
Better is a dry morsel, and quietness with it, than a house full of feasting with strife.
A wise servant will rule over a disgraceful son, and among brothers he will share the inheritance.
The crucible is for silver, and the furnace for gold, but the LORD tests hearts.
An evildoer listens to the lip of iniquity; a liar gives ear to a tongue of ruin.
He who mocks the poor reproaches his Maker, and he who rejoices at calamity shall not be unpunished.
Grandchildren are the crown of the aged, and the glory of children is their fathers.
Excellent speech is not fitting for a fool, much less lying lips for a noble.
A bribe is a stone of favor in the eyes of its possessor; wherever he turns, he prospers.
He who covers a transgression seeks love, but he who repeats a matter separates close friends.
A rebuke sinks deeper into one who understands than a hundred blows into a fool.
A rebellious man seeks only evil; therefore a cruel messenger shall be sent against him.
Let a man meet a she-bear robbed of her cubs, rather than a fool in his folly.
He who repays evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.
The letting out of water is the beginning of strife; so before the quarrel breaks out, abandon it.
He who justifies the wicked, and he who condemns the righteous, both of them alike are an abomination to the LORD.
Why is there a price in the hand of a fool to buy wisdom, when there is no heart for it?
A friend loves at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
A man lacking heart strikes hands, who becomes surety in the presence of his neighbor.
He who loves transgression loves strife; he who exalts his gate seeks destruction.
He who is crooked in heart will not find good, and he who is perverse in his tongue will fall into evil.
He who fathers a fool does so to his own sorrow, and the father of a senseless one shall not rejoice.
A merry heart does good like a healing, but a stricken spirit dries up the bones.
A wicked man takes a bribe from the bosom, to pervert the paths of justice.
Wisdom is before the face of him who understands, but the eyes of a fool are on the ends of the earth.
A foolish son is vexation to his father, and bitterness to her who bore him.
Also, to punish the righteous is not good, to strike noble men for uprightness.
He who restrains his words knows knowledge, and he who is cool of spirit is a man of understanding.
Even a fool, when he keeps silent, is counted wise; and he who shuts his lips is deemed understanding.
Whoever isolates himself seeks his own desire; against all sound wisdom he breaks out.
A fool takes no delight in understanding, but only in revealing his own heart.
When the wicked one comes, contempt also comes, and with dishonor comes reproach.
Deep waters are the words of a man’s mouth, a flowing stream, a fountain of wisdom.
To show favor to the wicked is not good, nor to turn aside the righteous in judgment.
The lips of a fool enter into strife, and his mouth calls for blows.
The mouth of a fool is his ruin, and his lips are a snare to his soul.
The words of a whisperer are like dainty morsels, and they go down into the innermost parts of the body.
Also, he who is slack in his work is a brother to one who destroys.
The name of the LORD is a strong tower; the righteous runs into it and is set on high.
The wealth of the rich is his strong city, and as a high wall in his own imagination.
Before destruction the heart of a man is lifted up, and before honor comes humility.
He who answers a matter before he hears it, it is folly and shame to him.
The spirit of a man will sustain his sickness, but a stricken spirit, who can bear it?
The heart of the discerning acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.
A man’s gift makes room for him, and brings him before great men.
The first to plead his cause seems right, until his neighbor comes and examines him.
The lot puts an end to quarrels, and separates between the mighty.
A brother offended is stronger than a fortified city, and quarrels are like the bars of a citadel.
From the fruit of a man’s mouth his belly shall be satisfied; with the increase of his lips he shall be filled.
Death and life are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it shall eat its fruit.
He who finds a wife finds good, and obtains favor from the LORD.
Supplications the poor man speaks, but the rich answers with harshness.
A man of many companions comes to ruin, but there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
Better is a poor man who walks in his integrity than one who is perverse in his lips and is a fool.
Also, that a soul be without knowledge is not good, and he who hurries with his feet sins.
A man’s foolishness twists his way, yet his heart rages against the LORD.
Wealth adds many friends, but the poor is separated from his friend.
A false witness shall not go unpunished, and he who breathes out lies shall not escape.
Many entreat the favor of a noble, and every man is a friend to him who gives gifts.
All the brothers of the poor man hate him; how much more do his friends withdraw far from him. He pursues words, yet they are not there.
He who acquires a heart loves his own soul; he who keeps understanding shall find good.
A false witness shall not go unpunished, and he who breathes out lies shall perish.
Luxury is not fitting for a fool, much less for a servant to rule over princes.
The prudence of a man makes him slow to anger, and it is his glory to pass over a transgression.
The wrath of a king is like the roaring of a young lion, but his favor is like dew upon the grass.
A foolish son is ruin to his father, and a contentious wife is a continual dripping.
House and wealth are an inheritance from fathers, but a prudent wife is from the LORD.
Laziness casts into deep sleep, and a deceitful soul shall hunger.
He who keeps the commandment keeps his soul, but he who despises his ways shall die.
He who shows favor to the poor lends to the LORD, and He will repay him for his deed.
Discipline your son, for there is hope; but do not set your heart on putting him to death.
A man of great wrath shall bear the penalty, for if you rescue him, you will yet have to do it again.
Hear counsel and receive instruction, that you may be wise in your latter end.
Many are the plans in a man’s heart, but the counsel of the LORD, that is what shall stand.
The desire of a man is his kindness, and a poor man is better than a liar.
The fear of the LORD leads to life, and he shall lodge satisfied; evil shall not be visited upon him.
The sluggard buries his hand in the dish; even to his mouth he will not bring it back.
Strike a scoffer, and the simple will become prudent; reprove one who is understanding, and he will gain knowledge.
He who despoils a father and drives away a mother is a son who brings shame and disgrace.
Cease, my son, to hear instruction that leads you to stray from the words of knowledge.
A worthless witness mocks at justice, and the mouth of the wicked swallows iniquity.
Judgments are prepared for scoffers, and blows for the backs of fools.
Wine is a mocker, strong drink a brawler, and whoever is led astray by it is not wise.
The terror of a king is as the roaring of a young lion; whoever provokes him to anger sins against his own life.
It is an honor for a man to cease from strife, but every fool will be quarrelsome.
Because of winter the sluggard will not plow; he shall ask in harvest, and there is nothing.
Deep waters are counsel in the heart of a man, and a man of understanding will draw it out.
Many a man will proclaim his own steadfast kindness, but a faithful man, who can find?
The righteous walks in his integrity; blessed are his children after him.
A king sitting on the throne of judgment winnows all evil with his eyes.
Who can say, “I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin”?
Differing weights and differing measures, both of them are an abomination to the LORD.
Even by his deeds a child makes himself known, whether his work is pure and whether it is right.
The hearing ear and the seeing eye, the LORD has made them both.
Do not love sleep, lest you come to poverty; open your eyes, and you shall be satisfied with bread.
“Bad, bad,” says the buyer; but when he goes his way, then he boasts.
There is gold, and a multitude of rubies, but the lips of knowledge are a precious vessel.
Take his garment, for he has become surety for a stranger, and for a foreign woman seize it as a pledge.
Bread of deceit is sweet to a man, but afterward his mouth shall be filled with gravel.
Plans are established by counsel, and with wise strategies wage war.
He who goes about as a talebearer reveals a secret; therefore do not associate with one who opens wide his lips.
Whoever curses his father or his mother, his lamp shall be put out in the pupil of darkness.
An inheritance gained hastily at the beginning, in the end shall not be blessed.
Do not say, “I will repay evil”; wait for the LORD, and he will save you.
Unequal weights are an abomination to the LORD, and deceitful balances are not good.
A man’s steps are from the LORD; how then can a person understand his own way?
It is a snare for a man to rashly declare, “Holy,” and only afterward to examine his vows.
A wise king winnows the wicked and turns the wheel over them.
The spirit of man is the lamp of the LORD, searching all the inward chambers of the body.
Lovingkindness and truth preserve the king, and by lovingkindness his throne is upheld.
The glory of young men is their strength, and the splendor of old men is gray hair.
Bruises and wounds scour away evil, and stripes reach the innermost parts of the belly.
The king’s heart is like streams of water in the hand of the LORD; he turns it wherever he wills.
Every way of a man is right in his own eyes, but the LORD weighs the hearts.
To do righteousness and justice is chosen by the LORD rather than sacrifice.
A high look and a proud heart, the plowing of the wicked, is sin.
The plans of the diligent surely lead to abundance, but everyone who is hasty surely comes to want.
The getting of treasures by a lying tongue is a fleeting vapor, those who seek death.
The violence of the wicked shall drag them away, because they refuse to do justice.
The way of a guilty man is crooked, but the work of the pure is upright.
Better to dwell on a corner of the housetop than with a quarrelsome wife in a shared house.
The soul of the wicked desires evil; his neighbor finds no mercy in his eyes.
When the scoffer is punished, the simple becomes wise; and when the wise is instructed, he receives knowledge.
The Righteous One wisely considers the house of the wicked; he overthrows the wicked for their ruin.
Whoever stops his ear at the cry of the poor, he also shall call and not be answered.
A gift in secret pacifies anger, and a bribe in the bosom fierce wrath.
It is joy to the righteous to do justice, but ruin to the workers of iniquity.
A man who wanders from the way of understanding shall rest in the assembly of the shades.
A man of want is he who loves pleasure; he who loves wine and oil will not become rich.
The wicked is a ransom for the righteous, and the treacherous in place of the upright.
Better to dwell in a land of wilderness than with a woman of strife and anger.
Precious treasure and oil are in the dwelling of the wise, but a foolish man devours them.
He who pursues righteousness and mercy finds life, righteousness, and honor.
A wise man scales the city of the mighty and brings down the strength of its trust.
Whoever keeps his mouth and his tongue keeps his soul from troubles.
A proud and arrogant man, scoffer is his name, who acts in the overflowing fury of presumption.
The desire of the sluggard puts him to death, for his hands refuse to work.
All the day long he covets with craving, but the righteous gives and does not withhold.
The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination; how much more when he brings it with evil intent.
A false witness shall perish, but a man who listens shall speak forever.
A wicked man hardens his face, but the upright considers his way.
There is no wisdom, nor understanding, nor counsel against the LORD.
The horse is made ready for the day of battle, but salvation belongs to the LORD.
A good name is to be chosen rather than great riches, and favor is better than silver and gold.
Rich and poor meet together; the LORD is the Maker of them all.
The prudent sees evil and hides himself, but the simple pass on and are punished.
The reward of humility and the fear of the LORD is riches and honor and life.
Thorns and snares are in the way of the crooked; whoever guards his soul will keep far from them.
Train up a child according to the way he should go; even when he grows old he will not depart from it.
The rich rules over the poor, and the borrower is servant to the lender.
He who sows injustice will reap trouble, and the rod of his wrath will come to an end.
He that has a bountiful eye shall be blessed, for he gives of his bread to the poor.
Cast out the scoffer, and strife will go out; yes, contention and dishonor will cease.
He who loves purity of heart, whose lips are gracious, the king is his friend.
The eyes of the LORD keep watch over knowledge, but he overturns the words of the treacherous.
The sluggard says, “There is a lion outside; I shall be slain in the streets.”
A deep pit is the mouth of strange women; he who is abhorred of the LORD shall fall there.
Foolishness is bound in the heart of a youth, but the rod of discipline will drive it far from him.
He who oppresses the poor to increase his own wealth, and he who gives to the rich, surely comes only to want.
Incline your ear and hear the words of the wise, and apply your heart to my knowledge.
For it is pleasant when you keep them within your inward parts; they shall all be established together upon your lips.
That your trust may be in the LORD, I have made them known to you today, even to you.
Have I not written to you excellent things in counsels and knowledge?
To make you know the certainty of words of truth, that you may return words of truth to those who send you.
Do not rob the poor because he is poor, and do not crush the afflicted in the gate.
For the LORD will plead their cause, and will rob of life those who rob them.
Do not befriend a man given to anger, and do not go with a wrathful man.
Lest you learn his ways and take a snare for your soul.
Do not be among those who strike hands in pledge, among those who become sureties for debts.
If you have nothing with which to pay, why should he take your bed from under you?
Do not remove the ancient boundary which your fathers have set.
Have you seen a man skillful in his work? He shall stand before kings; he shall not stand before obscure men.
When you sit to eat with a ruler, consider diligently what is before you.
And put a knife to your throat if you are a man given to appetite.
Do not crave his delicacies, for he is bread of lies.
Do not weary yourself to become rich; cease from your own understanding.
Will you set your eyes upon it, and it is gone? For it will surely make itself wings, like an eagle that flies toward heaven.
Do not eat the bread of one with an evil eye, nor desire his delicacies.
For as he has reckoned in his soul, so is he. “Eat and drink,” he says to you, but his heart is not with you.
Your morsel which you have eaten you shall vomit up, and you will have wasted your pleasant words.
Do not speak in the ears of a fool, for he will despise the wisdom of your words.
Do not remove the ancient boundary, and into the fields of the fatherless do not enter.
For their Redeemer is strong; he will plead their cause against you.
Apply your heart to discipline, and your ears to words of knowledge.
Do not withhold discipline from a child; if you strike him with the rod, he will not die.
You shall strike him with the rod, and you shall deliver his soul from Sheol.
My son, if your heart is wise, my heart also shall rejoice, even I.
And my inmost parts shall exult when your lips speak what is right.
Let not your heart envy sinners, but be in the fear of the LORD all the day long.
For surely there is a future, and your hope shall not be cut off.
Hear, my son, and be wise, and direct your heart in the way.
Do not be among winebibbers, among gluttonous eaters of flesh.
For the drunkard and the glutton shall come to poverty, and drowsiness shall clothe a man with rags.
Listen to your father who begot you, and do not despise your mother when she is old.
Buy the truth, and do not sell it; wisdom and instruction and understanding.
The father of the righteous will surely rejoice, and he who begets a wise son will be glad in him.
Let your father and your mother rejoice, and let her who bore you exult.
My son, give me your heart, and let your eyes delight in my ways.
For a harlot is a deep pit, and a foreign woman is a narrow well.
She also lies in wait like a robber, and increases the treacherous among men.
Who has woe? Who has sorrow? Who has strife? Who has complaining? Who has wounds without cause? Who has dimness of eyes?
For those who linger long over the wine, for those who go to search out mixed drink.
Do not look upon the wine when it is red, when it sparkles in the cup, when it goes down smoothly.
Its end will bite like a serpent, and sting like a viper.
Your eyes will behold strange things, and your heart will utter perverse things.
And you shall be like one who lies down in the heart of the sea, and like one who lies on the top of a mast.
They struck me, but I was not hurt; they beat me, but I did not know it. When shall I awake? I will seek it yet again.
Do not envy men of evil, and do not desire to be with them.
For their heart meditates on violence, and their lips speak of trouble.
By wisdom a house is built, and by understanding it is established.
And by knowledge the chambers are filled with all precious and pleasant riches.
A wise man is mighty in strength, and a man of knowledge increases power.
For by wise counsel you shall make war for yourself, and in a multitude of counselors there is deliverance.
Wisdom is too high for a fool; in the gate he does not open his mouth.
He who devises to do evil, they shall call him a master of schemes.
The devising of folly is sin, and a scoffer is an abomination to mankind.
If you faint in the day of adversity, your strength is small.
Deliver those who are being taken away to death, and hold back those who are stumbling to the slaughter.
If you say, “Behold, we did not know this,” does not He who weighs the hearts understand, and He who keeps your soul, does not He know it, and will He not repay a man according to his work?
Eat honey, my son, for it is good, and the honeycomb is sweet upon your palate.
So know wisdom for your soul: if you have found it, then there is a future, and your hope shall not be cut off.
Do not lie in wait, O wicked one, against the dwelling of the righteous; do not destroy his resting place.
For though a righteous man falls seven times, he rises again, but the wicked stumble in calamity.
When your enemy falls, do not rejoice, and when he stumbles, let not your heart be glad.
lest the LORD see it, and it be evil in his eyes, and he turn away his wrath from him
Do not fret yourself because of evildoers, and do not envy the wicked.
For there shall be no future for the evil man; the lamp of the wicked shall be put out.
Fear the LORD, my son, and the king; do not mingle with those who change.
For their calamity shall rise suddenly, and who knows the ruin of them both?
These also belong to the wise: to show partiality in judgment is not good.
He who says to the wicked, “You are righteous,” peoples shall curse him, nations shall abhor him.
But to those who rebuke, it shall be pleasant, and upon them shall come a blessing of good.
He kisses the lips who gives an upright answer.
Prepare your work outside, and make it ready for yourself in the field; afterward you shall build your house.
Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause, and do not deceive with your lips.
Do not say, “As he has done to me, so will I do to him; I will repay the man according to his work.”
I passed by the field of a sluggard, and by the vineyard of a man lacking heart.
And behold, it was all grown over with thorns; nettles had covered its surface, and its stone wall was broken down.
Then I myself beheld, I set my heart to it; I saw, I received instruction.
A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to lie down.
and your poverty comes like a prowler, and your want like an armed man.
These also are proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out.
It is the glory of God to conceal a matter, and the glory of kings to search out a matter.
The heavens for height, and the earth for depth, and the heart of kings is unsearchable.
Take away the dross from the silver, and there comes forth a vessel for the refiner.
Remove the wicked from before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.
Do not exalt yourself in the presence of a king, and do not stand in the place of the great.
For it is better that it be said to you, “Come up here,” than that you be put lower in the presence of a noble, whom your eyes have seen.
Do not go out hastily to strive, lest what you will do in the end, when your neighbor has put you to shame.
Plead your cause with your neighbor himself, and the secret of another do not reveal.
Lest he who hears it put you to shame, and your evil report not turn back.
Apples of gold in settings of silver is a word spoken in season.
A ring of gold and an ornament of fine gold, so is a wise reprover upon a listening ear.
Like the cold of snow in the day of harvest, so is a faithful messenger to those who send him, for he refreshes the soul of his masters.
Clouds and wind and no rain, so is a man who boasts of a false gift.
By long patience a ruler is persuaded, and a gentle tongue can break a bone.
Have you found honey? Eat only what is enough for you, lest you be filled with it and vomit it.
Let your foot be rare in your neighbor’s house, lest he be filled with you and come to hate you.
A war club, and a sword, and a sharp arrow is a man who answers against his neighbor as a false witness.
A bad tooth and an unsteady foot is the trust of a treacherous man in the day of distress.
Like one who takes away a garment on a cold day, and vinegar upon soda, so is he who sings songs to a troubled heart.
If your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he is thirsty, give him water to drink.
For you will heap coals of fire upon his head, and the LORD will repay you.
The north wind brings forth rain, and an angry countenance a secret tongue.
Better to dwell on the corner of a roof than with a quarrelsome wife in a shared house.
Like cold water to a weary soul, so is good news from a distant land.
A muddied spring and a corrupted fountain is a righteous man who gives way before the wicked.
It is not good to eat much honey, and searching out their own glory is glory.
A city broken down and without walls is a man who has no restraint over his spirit.
Like snow in summer and like rain in harvest, so honor is not fitting for a fool.
Like a sparrow in its flitting, like a swallow in its flying, so a curse without cause shall not come.
A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the back of fools.
Do not answer a fool according to his folly, lest you also be like him.
Answer a fool according to his folly, lest he be wise in his own eyes.
He cuts off his own feet and drinks violence who sends a message by the hand of a fool.
The legs of the lame hang limp, so is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
Like one who binds a stone in a sling, so is he who gives honor to a fool.
A thorn that goes up into the hand of a drunkard, so is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
A great one who forms all things, and he who hires a fool is like one who hires passersby.
Like a dog that returns to its vomit, so a fool repeats his folly.
Have you seen a man wise in his own eyes? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
The sluggard says, “A lion is in the way; a lion is in the streets.”
As the door turns upon its hinges, so does the sluggard upon his bed.
The sluggard buries his hand in the dish; it wearies him to bring it back to his mouth.
The sluggard is wiser in his own eyes than seven men who answer with discretion.
He who seizes a dog by the ears is one who passes by and becomes enraged over a quarrel not his own.
Like a madman who shoots firebrands, arrows, and death.
So is the man who deceives his neighbor, and says, “Am I not only joking?”
Where there is no wood, the fire goes out; and where there is no whisperer, strife grows quiet.
Charcoal for embers, and wood for fire; and a contentious man to kindle strife.
The words of a whisperer are like dainty morsels, and they go down into the innermost parts of the body.
Silver dross overlaid on an earthen vessel, so are burning lips and an evil heart.
He who hates disguises himself with his lips, but within him he lays up deceit.
When he makes his voice gracious, do not believe in him, for seven abominations are in his heart.
Though hatred is covered by deceit, his wickedness shall be revealed in the assembly.
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it, and he who rolls a stone, it will return upon him.
A lying tongue hates those it crushes, and a flattering mouth works ruin.
Do not boast yourself of tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring forth.
Let another praise you, and not your own mouth; a stranger, and not your own lips.
A stone is heavy, and the sand a burden, but the anger of a fool is heavier than both of them.
Wrath is cruel, and anger is a flood; but who can stand before jealousy?
Better is open rebuke than hidden love.
Faithful are the wounds of a friend, but profuse are the kisses of an enemy.
The satisfied soul tramples honeycomb, but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
Like a bird that wanders from her nest, so is a man who wanders from his place.
Oil and incense gladden the heart, and the sweetness of a friend comes from earnest counsel of the soul.
Do not forsake your friend and your father’s friend, and do not enter your brother’s house in the day of your calamity; better is a neighbor who is near than a brother far away.
Be wise, my son, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him who reproaches me.
The prudent sees evil and hides himself, but the simple pass on and are punished.
Take his garment, for he has become surety for a stranger, and for a foreign woman seize it as a pledge.
He who blesses his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.
A continual dripping on a day of steady rain, and a contentious wife are alike.
Whoever would restrain her restrains the wind, and his right hand encounters oil.
Iron is sharpened by iron, and a man sharpens the countenance of his friend.
He who tends the fig tree shall eat its fruit, and he who guards his master shall be honored.
As in water face answers to face, so the heart of man to man.
Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied, and the eyes of man are never satisfied.
The crucible is for silver, and the furnace for gold, and a man is proved by the mouth of his praise.
Though you pound a fool in a mortar among grain with a pestle, yet his folly will not depart from him.
Know well the state of your flocks; set your heart to the herds.
For riches are not forever, and does a crown endure to every generation?
The hay is carried away, and the tender grass appears, and the herbs of the mountains are gathered in.
The lambs are for your clothing, and the goats are the price of a field.
And there will be enough goats’ milk for your food, for the bread of your household, and sustenance for your maidens.
The wicked flee when no man pursues, but the righteous are bold as a young lion.
By the transgression of a land its rulers are many, but by a man of understanding and knowledge its stability shall be prolonged.
A poor man who oppresses the lowly is like a sweeping rain that leaves no bread.
Those who forsake the law praise the wicked, but those who keep the law contend with them.
Evil men do not understand justice, but those who seek the LORD understand all things.
Better is a poor man who walks in his integrity than one who is crooked in his ways, though he is rich.
He who keeps the law is a discerning son, but a companion of gluttons disgraces his father.
He who increases his wealth by interest and usury gathers it for him who shows favor to the poor.
He who turns away his ear from hearing the law, even his prayer is an abomination.
Whoever leads the upright astray in an evil way, he shall fall into his own pit, but the blameless shall inherit good.
A rich man is wise in his own eyes, but a poor man that has understanding will search him out.
When the righteous rejoice, great is the glory; but when the wicked rise, a man is sought out.
He who covers his transgressions shall not prosper, but whoever confesses and forsakes them shall obtain mercy.
Blessed is the man who is always fearful, but he who hardens his heart will fall into evil.
A roaring lion and a charging bear is a wicked ruler over a poor people.
A ruler lacking understanding is also a great oppressor, but he who hates unjust gain will prolong his days.
A man burdened with the blood of a soul will flee to the pit; let no one support him.
Whoever walks blamelessly shall be saved, but he who is perverse in his ways shall fall at once.
He who works his land will be satisfied with bread, but he who pursues vain things will be satisfied with poverty.
A faithful man will abound with blessings, but he who hastens to be rich shall not go unpunished.
To show partiality is not good, and for a piece of bread a man will transgress.
A man with an evil eye hastens after wealth, and does not know that want will come upon him.
He who reproves a man afterward shall find favor, more than he who flatters with the tongue.
Whoever robs his father or his mother and says, “It is no transgression,” is a companion to a man who destroys.
The proud of soul stirs up strife, but he who trusts in the LORD shall be made fat.
He who trusts in his own heart is a fool, but he who walks in wisdom shall be delivered.
He who gives to the poor shall not lack, but he who hides his eyes shall have many curses.
When the wicked rise, a man hides himself; but when they perish, the righteous increase.
A man who is often reproved yet stiffens his neck shall suddenly be broken, and there will be no healing.
When the righteous are many, the people rejoice, but when a wicked man rules, the people groan.
A man who loves wisdom makes his father glad, but a companion of harlots wastes wealth.
A king by justice establishes the land, but a man of bribes tears it down.
A man who flatters his neighbor spreads a net for his steps.
In the transgression of an evil man there is a snare, but the righteous sings and rejoices.
The righteous knows the cause of the poor, but the wicked does not understand such knowledge.
Men of scoffing set a city aflame, but the wise turn back wrath.
A wise man enters into judgment with a foolish man, and he rages or laughs, yet there is no rest.
Men of blood hate the blameless, but the upright seek his life.
A fool lets all his spirit burst forth, but a wise man holds it back in quiet restraint.
A ruler who listens to a lying word, all his ministers are wicked.
The poor man and the man of oppressions meet together; the LORD gives light to the eyes of them both.
A king who judges the poor in truth, his throne shall be established forever.
The rod and reproof give wisdom, but a child left to himself brings shame to his mother.
When the wicked are multiplied, transgression increases; but the righteous shall look on their downfall.
Discipline your son, and he will give you rest; yes, he will give delight to your soul.
Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint; but he who keeps the law, happy is he.
By mere words a servant will not be corrected, for he understands, yet there is no response.
Do you see a man hasty in his words? There is more hope for a fool than for him.
He who pampers his servant from youth, in the end he will become a son of entitlement.
A man of anger stirs up strife, and a master of wrath abounds in transgression.
A man's pride will bring him low, but he who is of a lowly spirit will obtain honor.
He who shares with a thief hates his own soul; he hears the adjuration and does not disclose it.
The fear of man lays a snare, but whoever trusts in the LORD shall be set on high.
Many seek the face of the ruler, but from the LORD comes the judgment of a man.
An unjust man is an abomination to the righteous, and he who is upright in the way is an abomination to the wicked.
The words of Agur son of Jakeh, the oracle; the utterance of the man to Ithiel, to Ithiel and Ucal.
For I am more brutish than a man, and have not the understanding of a human being.
And I have not learned wisdom, nor do I know the knowledge of the Holy One.

Who has ascended into heaven and come down? Who has gathered the wind in the hollow of his hands? Who has bound the waters in a garment? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is his name, and what is his son’s name, if you know?
Every word of God is refined; he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
Do not add to His words, lest He reprove you, and you be found a liar.
Two things I have asked of you; do not withhold them from me before I die.
Falsehood and a lying word put far from me; poverty and riches give me not; feed me with the bread that is my portion.
Lest I be full and deny, and say, “Who is the LORD?” or lest I be poor and steal, and profane the name of my God.
Do not slander a servant to his master, lest he curse you and you be found guilty.
A generation that curses its father and does not bless its mother.
A generation that is pure in its own eyes, yet is not washed from its filth.
A generation, how lofty are its eyes, and its eyelids are lifted up.
A generation whose teeth are swords, and whose jaw teeth are knives, to devour the poor from the earth and the needy from among men.
The leech has two daughters, “Give, give.” Three there are that are never satisfied, four that never say, “Enough.”
Sheol, and the barren womb, the earth that is not satisfied with water, and the fire that never says, “Enough.”
The eye that mocks a father and scorns to obey a mother, the ravens of the valley will pluck it out, and the young eagles will eat it.
Three things there are which are too wonderful for me, and four which I do not understand.
The way of the eagle in the heavens, the way of a serpent upon a rock, the way of a ship in the heart of the sea, and the way of a man with a maiden.
So is the way of an adulterous woman: she eats, and wipes her mouth, and says, “I have done no wickedness.”
Under three things the earth trembles, and under four it cannot bear up.
Under a servant when he reigns, and a fool when he is filled with bread.
Under a hated woman when she is married, and a maidservant when she displaces her mistress.
Four there are, the small ones of the earth, yet they are exceedingly wise.
The ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their food in the summer.
The rock badgers are a people not mighty, yet they make their house in the rock.
The locusts have no king, yet they all go forth in ranks.
The lizard you may seize with the hands, yet it is in kings’ palaces.
Three there are that go well in their stride, and four that are comely in their going.
The lion, mighty among beasts, who does not turn back before any.
The strutting of the loins, or a he-goat, and a king against whom there is no rising up.
If you have been foolish in exalting yourself, and if you have devised evil, lay your hand upon your mouth.
For as the churning of milk brings forth butter, and the wringing of the nose brings forth blood, so the forcing of anger brings forth strife.
The words of Lemuel, the king; an oracle that his mother taught him.
What, my son? And what, son of my womb? And what, son of my vows?
Do not give your strength to women, nor your ways to that which destroys kings.
It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine, nor for rulers to crave strong drink.
Lest he drink and forget what is decreed, and pervert the justice of all the afflicted.
Give strong drink to him who is perishing, and wine to those bitter of soul.
Let him drink and forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more.
Open your mouth for the mute, for the cause of all the children of passing away.
Open your mouth, judge righteously, and plead the cause of the poor and needy.
A woman of valor, who can find? For her worth is far above rubies.
The heart of her husband trusts in her, and he will have no lack of gain.
She deals out good to him and not evil all the days of her life.
She seeks wool and flax, and works with willing hands.
She is like the merchant ships; from afar she brings her food.
She rises while it is still night, and gives food to her household, and a portion to her maidens.
She considers a field and acquires it; from the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.
She girds her loins with strength, and makes strong her arms.
She perceives that her merchandise is good; her lamp does not go out by night.
Her hands she stretches out to the distaff, and her palms grasp the spindle.
She stretches out her hand to the poor, and she reaches forth her hands to the needy.
She is not afraid for her household because of snow, for all her household are clothed in scarlet.
Coverlets she makes for herself; fine linen and purple are her clothing.
Her husband is known in the gates, when he sits among the elders of the land.
She makes linen garments and sells them, and delivers sashes to the merchant.
Strength and splendor are her clothing, and she laughs at the day to come.
She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
She watches well the ways of her household, and the bread of idleness she does not eat.
Her children rise up and call her blessed; her husband also, and he praises her.
Many daughters have done nobly, but you excel them all.
Charm is deceitful and beauty is vain, but a woman who fears the LORD, she shall be praised.
Give her of the fruit of her hands, and let her works praise her in the gates.
